article.title: Craven_Cottage
article.paragraph:
multiple issuesMay 2012}} {{refimprove|dateUse dmy datesAugust 2014Use British EnglishJuly 2011Infobox stadiumCraven Cottage The Cottage, Fortress Fulham [[File:Craven Cottage Football Ground - geograph.org.uk - 778731.jpg|300px]] [[Fulham]], [[London]], SW6 6HH {{Coord|51|28|30|N|0|13|18|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display1780 1896 (as a stadium) [[Fulham F.C.]] Fulham F.C. Grass (Fibrelastic) Length 100m Width 65m[http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/handbooks/premier-league-handbook-2013-14.pdf BPL Handbook 13/14] [[Archibald Leitch]]<ref name[[Fulham F.C.]] (1896–2002, 2004–present)
[[Fulham L.F.C.]] (2000–2003)
[[Harlequins Rugby League#Fulham Rugby League Club|Fulham Rugby League Club]] ([[Rugby Football League Championship|RFL Championship]]) (1980–1984) 25,700<ref name49,335 (October 1938) Craven Cottageis the name of a footballstadiumlocated inFulham,London. It has been the home ground ofFulham F.C.since 1896.The ground's current capacity is 25,700,all-seated, though the record attendance is 49,335, for a game againstMillwall FCMillwall Dockers, 8 October 1938.cite webhttp://espnfc.com/feature/_/id/841079?ccA brief history of FulhamRobSmythESPNFC5 July 201218 November 2013Located next toBishop's Park (Fulham)Bishop's Parkon the banks of theRiver Thames,cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/visit/craven-cottage/cafe-at-the-cottageCafé at the CottageFulham F.C.18 November 2013'Craven Cottage' was originally a royal hunting lodge and has history dating back over 300 years.cite bookhttp://books.google.co.uk/books?idThe football and real ale guide: PremiershipRichardStedmanStedders Guides200618 November 2013

As well as by Fulham, the stadium has been also been used by theUnited States men's national soccer team,cite webhttp://www.espnfc.us/international-friendly/match/408559/united-states-colombia/reportColombia come from behind to beat United States at Craven CottageESPN14 November 201414 November 2014Australia national soccer team,cite webhttp://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/socceroos-beat-nigeria/story-e6frf9if-1111114903446Carney leads Australia to 1-0 victory over Nigeria''Herald Sun''18 November 200718 November 2013theRepublic of Ireland national football team,cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19564967Republic of Ireland 4-1 OmanBBC Sport11 September 201218 November 2013andCanada men's national soccer team,cite webhttp://o.canada.com/sports/australia-crushes-canada-in-soccer-friendly/Australia crushes Canada in soccer friendlycanada.com15 October 201318 November 2013and was formerly the home ground forrugby leagueteamFulham RLFC.cite webhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/rugbyunion/article-1107285/Sarries-Thames-Ambitious-Fez-Heads-plot-Craven-Cottage.htmlSarries-on-Thames: Ambitious Fez Heads plot move to Fulham's Craven CottagePeterJackson''Daily Mail''7 January 200918 November 2013
article.heading: History
Pre-Fulham
article.paragraph: File:Craven Cottage LH4736.jpgthumbrightAerial view of Craven Cottage on the banks of theRiver Thamesas it looks todayThe original 'Cottage' was built in 1780, byWilliam Craven, 6th Baron CravenWilliam Craven, the sixthBaron Cravencite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2011/may/20/a-place-in-historyA Place In HistoryFulham F.C.20 May 201118 November 2013and was located on the centre circle of the pitch. At the time, the surrounding areas were woods which made up part ofAnne Boleyn's hunting grounds.

The Cottage was lived in byEdward Bulwer-Lytton, 1st Baron LyttonEdward Bulwer-Lytton(who wroteThe Last Days of Pompeiicite webhttp://www.amazon.com/Last-Days-Pompeii-Dodo-Press/dp/1406521647The Last Days of PompeiiEdwardBulwer-Lytton''Dodo Press''19 November 2013) and other somewhat notable (and moneyed) personsuntil it was destroyed by fire in May 1888.Many rumours persist among Fulham fans of past tenants of Craven Cottage.Sir Arthur Conan Doyle,Jeremy Bentham,Florence Nightingaleand evenQueen Victoriaare reputed to have stayed there, although there is no real evidence for this. Following the fire, the site was abandoned.Fulham had had 8 previous groundscite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2013/july/01/moments-that-made-ffc50 Moments That Made Fulham: 10. The Formation of the Club - 1879Fulham F.C.1 July 201319 November 2013before settling in at Craven Cottage for good. Therefore, The Cottagers have had 12 grounds overall (including a temporary stay atLoftus Roadcite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2013/september/11/top-10-loftus-road-matchesTop 10: Loftus Road MatchesFulham F.C.11 September 201319 November 2013), meaning that only their former 'landlords' and rivalsQueens Park Rangers F.C.QPRhave had more home grounds (14) in British football. Of particular note, wasRanelagh House, Fulham's palatial home from 18861888.cite webhttp://www.derelictlondon.com/londons-long-lost-sports-grounds.htmlLondon's Long Lost Sports GroundsDerelict London19 November 2013
article.heading: Under construction: 18941905
article.paragraph: File:Rabbit Hutch at the Cottage.jpgthumbrightThe 'Rabbit Hutch' stand along Stevenage Road beforeArchibald Leitch's redesign in 1904-5When representatives of Fulham first came across the land, in 1894, it was so overgrown that it took two years to be made suitable for football to be played on it.A deal was struck for the owners of the ground to carry out the work, in return for which they would receive a proportion of the gate receipts.

The first football match at which there were any gate receipts was when Fulham played against Minerva in theMiddlesex Senior Cup, on 10 October 1896.The ground's first stand was built shortly after.Described as looking like an "orange box", it consisted of four wooden structures each holding some 250 seats, and later was affectionately nicknamed the "rabbit hutch".

In 1904London County Councilbecame concerned with the level of safety at the ground, and tried to get it closed.A court case followed in January 1905, as a result of whichArchibald Leitch, a Scottisharchitectwho had risen to prominence after his building of theIbrox Stadium, a few years earlier,cite webhttp://www.therangersarchive.co.uk/index.php?optionArchibald Leitch - 'Engineering Archie': The Designer of IbroxThe Rangers Archive19 November 2013was hired to work on the stadium.In a scheme costing 15,000(a record for the timecite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19009781Fulham's plans to increase Craven Cottage capacity approvedBBC Sport27 July 201219 November 2013), he built a pavilion (the present-day 'Cottage' itself) and the Stevenage Road Stand,in his characteristicred brickstyle.

The stand on Stevenage Road celebrated its centenary in the 20052006 seasoncite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2005/august/15/stevenage-road-centenaryStevenage Road CentenaryFulham F.C.15 August 200519 November 2013and, following the death of Fulham FC's favourite son, former England captainJohnny Haynes, in a car accident in October 2005cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4353732.stmLegendary Haynes dies after crashBBC Sport18 October 200519 November 2013the Stevenage Road Stand was renamed the Johnny Haynes Stand after the club sought the opinions of Fulham supporters.cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/f/fulham/4480816.stmFulham re-name stand after HaynesBBC Sport29 November 200519 November 2013

File:Fulham Football Club - geograph.org.uk - 577777.jpgthumbrightThe facade of the Johnny Haynes standBoth the Johnny Haynes Stand and Cottage remain among the finest examples ofArchibald Leitchfootball architecture to remain in existence and both have been designated as Grade II listed buildings.
article.heading: Establishing itself as a stadium
article.paragraph: AnEngland national football teamEnglandvWales national football teamWalesmatch was played at the ground in 1907,cite webhttp://www.englandstats.com/matches.php?midEngland 1 - 1 WalesEngland Stats18 March 190719 November 2013cite webhttps://sites.google.com/site/englandmatchreports/090-wales-1907England 1 - 1 WalesEngland Match Reports18 March 190719 November 2013followed by arugby leagueinternational betweenEngland national rugby league teamEnglandandAustralia national rugby league teamAustraliain 1911.cite webhttp://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/matches/kangaroos-tour-1911/game-7/england-vs-australia.htmlEngland 6 lost to Australia 11The Rugby League Project18 October 201119 November 2013

One of the club's directorsHenry Norris (businessman)Henry Norris, and his friend William Hall, took overArsenal F.C.Arsenalin the early 1910s,cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/history/laying-the-foundations/club-moves-from-woolwich-to-highburyClub moves from Woolwich to HighburyArsenal F.C.16 December 200819 November 2013the plan being to merge Fulham with Arsenal,cite webhttp://www.arsenal.com/history/arsenal-stadium-highbury/arsenal-stadium-a-historyHighbury - A historyArsenal F.C.14 July 200819 November 2013to form a "London superclub" at Craven Cottage.cite bookhttp://books.google.co.uk/books?idRebels for the Cause: The Alternative History of Arsenal Football ClubJonSpurlingRandom House2 November 201219 November 2013This move was largely motivated by Fulham's failure thus far to gain promotion to the top division of English football. There were also plans for Henry Norris to build a larger stadium on the other side of Stevenage Road but there was little need after the merger idea failed. During this era, the Cottage was used for choir singing and marching bands along with other performances, and Mass.cite av mediahttp://www.youtube.com/watch?vCraven Cottage 192616 November 2010YouTubecite av mediahttp://www.youtube.com/watch?vCraven Cottage Charity Match 192016 November 2010YouTube
In 1933 there were plans to demolish the ground and start again from scratch with a new 80,000 capacity stadium. These plans never materialised mainly due to theGreat Depression.

On 8 October 1938, 49,335 spectators watched Fulham playMillwall F.C.Millwall.The reason for this exceptionally large crowd was that the game at Stamford Bridge had suddenly been cancelled and so a lot of people made their way west to the Cottage that afternoon instead. It was the largest attendance ever at Craven Cottage and the record remains today, unlikely to be bettered as it is now an all-seater stadium with currently no room for more than 25,700. During the 1930-60's era, Fulham often averaged over 25,000. However, the official attendances can be considered somewhat dubious in this era as many fans would get in by climbing over the fence from Bishops Park into the Putney End. As at many other grounds, fans would sometimes pay at the turnstiles but not be counted. ThisBoot money scandalboot moneywould be given to the players (stuffed in their boots) and would not be counted in the gate money. The ground hosted several football games for the1948 Summer Olympics, and is one of the last extant that did.1948 Summer Olympics official report.pp. 456.
article.heading: Post-War
article.paragraph: File:Johnny Haynes statue.jpgthumbrightuprightJohnny Haynes, Fulham's most famous player, in his classic 'hand-on-hip' pose, outside the stand named after himIt wasn't until after Fulham first reached the top division, in 1949, that further improvements were made to the stadium. In 1962 Fulham became the final side in the first division to erect floodlights.cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2013/august/22/throwback-thursday1962: Cook Lights Up The CottageFulham F.C.22 August 201319 November 2013The floodlights were said to be the most expensive in Europe at the time as they were so modern. The lights were like large pylons towering 50 metres over the ground and were similar in appearance to those at theWACA GroundWACA. An electronic scoreboard was installed on the Riverside Terrace at the same time as the floodlights were installed and flagpoles flying the flags of all of the other first division teams were flown from them.cite webhttp://www.whoateallthepies.tv/fulham/171403/the-black-and-white-years-scorching-vintage-photos-of-fulhams-craven-cottage-between-1923-1978.htmlThe Black-And-White Years: Scorching Vintage Photos Of Fulham’s Craven Cottage, Between 1923-1978ChrisWrightWho Ate All The Pies?30 July 201321 November 2013Following the sale of Alan Mullery to Tottenham Hotspur in 1964 (for 72,500) the Hammersmith End had a roof put over itcite webhttp://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/fulham-go-from-laughing-stock-to-serious-players-1947790.htmlFulham go from laughing stock to serious playersSteveTongue''Independent''18 April 201021 November 2013at a cost of approximately 42,500.

Although Fulham was relegated, the development of Craven Cottage continued. The Riverside terracing, infamous for the fact that fans occupying it would turn their heads annually to watchThe Boat Racepass,cite bookhttp://books.google.co.uk/books?idFootball Fanatic: A Record Breaking Journey Through English FootballKenFerrisRandom House1 March 201319 November 2013was replaced by what was officially named the 'Eric Miller Stand',cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16531444Fulham submit plans to expand Craven Cottage to a 30,000-seat stadiumBBC Sport12 January 201219 November 2013Eric Miller (businessman)Eric Millerbeing a director of the club at the time.cite webhttp://www.theguardian.com/football/2003/jan/18/sport.comment1'The Cottage has been a block of flats waiting to happen since the 1980s'DavidLacey''Guardian''18 January 200319 November 2013The stand, which cost 334,000and held 4,200 seats, was opened with a friendly game againstS.L. BenficaBenficain February 1972, (which includedEusbio).cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2013/june/06/throwback-thursday1972: Riverside RoyaltyFulham F.C.6 June 201319 November 2013Pelwas also to appear on the ground, with a friendly played against his teamSantos F.C.cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2013/may/30/throwback-thursday1973: Pelé Plays At The CottageFulham F.C.30 May 201319 November 2013The Miller stand bought the seated capacity up to 11,000 out of a total 40,000.cite av mediahttp://www.youtube.com/watch?vFulham v Burnley 19729 August 2011YouTubeEric Miller (businessman)Eric Millercommitted suicide five years later after a political and financial scandal,cite webhttp://news.google.com/newspapers?nidMPs may debate scandal of suicide tycoon''Glasgow Herald''31 January 197919 November 2013and had shady dealing with trying to move Fulham away from the Cottage. The stand is now better known as the Riverside Stand.

OnBoxing Day1963, Craven Cottage was the venue of the fastesthat-trick#Association footballhat-trickin the history of the English football league, which was completed in less than three minutes, byGraham Leggat. This helped his Fulham team to beatIpswich Town F.C.Ipswich101 (a club record).Three minutes is the time quoted byhis official website.cite webhttp://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/incoming/article6235.ece/BINARY/Fulham+10-1+IpswichTen for The 'Turkeys'BillHolden''Daily Mirror''27 December 196318 November 2013The international record is held byJimmy O'Connor, anRepublic of IrelandIrishplayer who notched up his hat trick in 2 minutes 14 seconds in 1967.cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/bournemouth/3485294.stmHayter keeps feet on groundMarkMitchenerBBC Sport25 February 200419 November 2013

Between 1980 and 1984,Fulhamrugby leagueplayed their home games at the Cottage.They have since evolved into theLondon Crusaders, theLondon BroncosandHarlequins Rugby Leaguebefore reverting toLondon Broncosahead ofSuper League XVIIthe 2012 season.cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/rugby-league/15353867Harlequins revert to London Broncos name again for 2012BBC Sport1 November 201119 November 2013Craven Cottage held the team's largest ever crowd at any ground with 15,013, at a game againstWakefield Trinity WildcatsWakefield Trinityon 15 February 1981.cite webhttp://www.napit.co.uk/viewus/infobank/rugby/superleague/harlequinsrl.phpHarlequins RLFCNapit19 November 2013
article.heading: Modern times

link.part: Craven Cottage prior to the implementation of theTaylor report.
The historic triangular gable on top of the Haynes stand, one of the few extant at British grounds

preblock.preline: When theHillsborough disasteroccurred, Fulham were in the second bottom rung ofThe Football League,cite webhttp://www.statto.com/football/teams/fulham/1988-1989/tableFulham 1988-1989 : English Division Three (old) TableStatto20 November 2013but following theTaylor reportFulham's ambitious chairman Jimmy Hill tabled plans in 1996 for an all-seater stadium.cite webhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/2395783/Fulham-pushed-out-Hill.htmlFulham pushed out HillMihirBose''Daily Telegraph''7 February 200320 November 2013These plans never came to fruition, partly due to local residents' pressure groups, and by the time Fulham reached thePremier LeaguePremiership, they still had standing areas in the ground,something virtually unheard of at the time. A year remained to do something about this (teams reaching the second tier for the first time are allowed a three-year period to reach the required standards for the top two divisions),cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/plymouth_argyle/6740273.stmPlymouth forced to close terraceBBC Sport2 August 201220 November 2013cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19095689Peterborough back calls for safe standing at football groundsBBC Sport11 June 200720 November 2013cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-essex-12600812Colchester MP wants return of football standing areasBBC News28 February 201120 November 2013but by the time the last league game was played there, againstLeicester City F.C.Leicester Cityon 27 April 2002, no building plansCite webhttp://www.buildersservicesfulham.co.uk/Builders In Fulham2015-04-152015Builders in Fulham,Londonhad been made. Two moreIntertoto Cupgames were played there later that year (againstFC Hakaof Finlandcite webhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/fulham/3030674/Intertoto-Cup-Fulhams-tepid-farewell-to-home.htmlIntertoto Cup: Fulham's tepid farewell to homeGarySlater''Daily Telegraph''7 July 200220 November 2013andEgaleo FCof Greececite webhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/fulham/3031317/Intertoto-Cup-Saha-saves-the-day-for-Fulham.htmlIntertoto Cup: Saha saves the day for FulhamAndrewWalshaw''Daily Telegraph''21 July 200220 November 2013), and the eventual solution was to decamp toLoftus Road, home of local rivalsQueens Park Rangers F.C.QPR.cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/1800444.stmFulham's Loftus Road switchBBC Sport4 February 200220 November 2013During this time, many Fulham fans only went to away games in protest of moving from Craven Cottage.cite webhttp://espnfc.com/news/story?idAl Fayed wants 'Fortress Cottage'ESPN FC8 July 200420 November 2013cite webhttp://lostboyos.wordpress.com/2013/01/02/lost-in-fulham/Lost in…FulhamLost Boyos2 January 201320 November 2013cite webhttp://www.friendsoffulham.com/forum/index.php?topicFulham messageboard discussionFriends of Fulham20 November 2013'Back to the Cottage', later to become the 'Fulham Supporters Trust', was set up as a fans pressure group to encourage the chairman and his advisers that Craven Cottage was the only viable option for Fulham Football Club.cite av mediahttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v1964 - 1965 - Fulham v Man United21 January 2009YouTubecite av mediahttp://www.youtube.com/watch?featureCraven Cottage Film22 December 2008YouTube

article.paragraph: After one and a half seasons at Loftus Road, no work had been done on the Cottage. In December 2003, plans were unveiled for 8million worth of major refurbishment work to bring it in line with Premier League requirements.cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/f/fulham/3326021.stmFulham return to CottageBBC Sport16 December 200320 November 2013cite webhttp://legacy.london.gov.uk/mayor/planning_decisions/strategic_dev/2004/jan0704/craven_cottage_appendix.pdfCraven Cottage Stadium (Fulham Football Club)Greater London Authority3 December 200320 November 2013With planning permission granted, work began in January 2004 in order to meet the deadline of the new season. The work proceeded as scheduled and the club were able to return to their home for the start of the200405 FA Premier League200405 season. Their first game in the new-look 22,000 all-seater stadium was a pre-season friendly against Watford on 10 July 2004.

The current stadium was one of thePremier LeaguePremiership'ssmallest grounds at the time of Fulham's relegation at the end of the201314 Premier League201314season (it was third-smallest, after theKC Stadiumand theLiberty Stadium).cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-22940442Cardiff City plan stadium expansion in time for 2014/15 seasonBBC News17 June 201320 November 2013Much admired for its fine architecture,cite webhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/11767726/Ranking-all-54-stadiums-in-Premier-League-history.html?frameRanking all 54 stadiums in Premier League history3 August 2015Telegraph.co.ukthe stadium has recently hosted a few international games, mostly includingAustralia national association football teamAustralia. This venue is suitable for Australia because most of the country's top players are based in Europe, and West London has a significant community ofexpatriateAustralians. Also,Greece national football teamGreecevs.Korea Republic national football teamSouth Koreawas hosted on 6 February 2007.cite webhttp://espnfc.com/match?idMatch: Greece v South Korea - International FriendlyESPN FC6 February 200720 November 2013In 2011 Brazil played Ghana, in an international friendly,cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14798121Brazil 1-0 GhanaBBC Sport5 September 201120 November 2013and the2011 UEFA Women's Champions League FinalWomen's Champions League Finalwas hosted.cite webhttp://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/may/26/lyon-turbine-potsdam-womens-champions-leagueWendie Renard and Lara Dickenmann make amends as Lyon see off PotsdamPaulDoyle''Guardian''26 May 201120 November 2013

Craven Cottage often hosts many other events such as 5-a-side football tournaments and weddings.cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/visit/experiences-and-events/weddingsWeddingsFulham F.C.20 November 2013Also, many have Sunday Lunch at the Riverside restaurantcite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/hospitality/packages/riverside-restaurantRiverside RestaurantFulham F.C.20 November 2013or the 'Cottage Cafe'on non-match days. Craven Cottage hosted theOxbridgeVarsity Football match annually between 1991 and 2000 and again in 2003, 2006 (the same day as the famous 'The Boat RaceBoat Race'cite webhttp://www.ox.ac.uk/media/news_stories/2006/060321_1.htmlhttp://www.ox.ac.uk/media/news_stories/2006/060321_1.htmlUniversity of Oxford21 March 200620 November 2013), 2008 and 2009,cite webhttp://www.ouafc.com/varsity-matches/indexList of Varsity matchesOxford University A.F.C.9 December 200920 November 2013and will once again host it in 2014cite webhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/fulham/10395031/Oxford-University-v-Cambridge-University-varsity-match-set-to-return-to-Fulhams-Craven-Cottage.htmlOxford University v Cambridge University varsity match set to return to Fulham's Craven CottageHenryWinter''Daily Telegraph''21 October 201320 November 2013as well as having aSoccer Aidwarm-up match in 2006.cite webhttp://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-previews/soccer-aid-626142Soccer AidJaneSimon''Daily Mirror''23 May 200620 November 2013The half-time entertainment often includes the SW6erscite webhttp://cafcbois.blogspot.co.uk/2006/04/match-report-fulham-2-1-charlton.htmlMatch Report: Fulham 2 - 1 CharltonJamesDa LionCAFC Bois15 April 200620 November 2013(previously called The Cravenettescite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2001/december/03/monday-s-mediaRe-print of reports of Fulham 0-0 Leeds United on Fulham official website''The Times''3 December 200120 November 2013cite webhttp://www.flickr.com/photos/jjwillow/3218040453/in/photostream/The CravenettesJohnWilloghbyFlickr1 January 200620 November 2013) which are a group of female cheerleaders. However, other events have included brass bands,Michael Jackson(albeit just walking on the pitch once, as opposed to performing),cite av mediahttp://www.youtube.com/watch?vMichael Jackson at Fulham football ground25 November 2010YouTubeTravis (band)Travisplaying, Arabic dancing,keepie uppieprofessionals and presentational awards. Most games also feature the 'Fulham flutter', a half-time draw;cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2007/april/17/text-for-fulham-flutterText for Fulham FlutterFulham F.C.17 April 200720 November 2013and a shoot-out competition of some kind,cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/help/faq/stadium-experienceStadium ExperienceFulham F.C.20 November 2013usually involving scoring through a 'hoop' or 'beat the goalie'. On the first home game of the season, there is a carnival where every Fulham fan is expected to turn up in black-and-white colours. There is usually live rock bands, player signings, clowns, stilt walkers, a steel (calypso) band, food stalls and a free training session for children in Bishops Park.

TheFulham L.F.C.Fulham Ladies(before their demise)cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/women/4988138.stmBBC SPORT - Football - Women - Fulham pull plug on women's teambbc.co.ukand Reserve teams occasionally play home matches at the Cottage. Other than this, they generally play at the club's training ground atMotspur Parkor atKingstonian F.C.KingstonianandAFC Wimbledon's stadium,Kingsmeadow. Craven Cottage is known by several affectionate nicknames from fans, including: The (River) Cottage,cite webhttp://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/sport/football/clubs/fulham/article2301454.eceReturn to river Cottage key to Coleman’s home comfortNickSzczepanik''The Times''21 August 200420 November 2013subscriptioncite webhttp://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/fulham-1-stoke-0-relief-at-the-cottage-as-late-darren-bent-strike-lifts-martin-jols-men-out-of-the-drop-zone-8861070.htmlFulham 1 Stoke 0: Relief at the Cottage as late Darren Bent strike lifts Martin Jol's men out of the drop zoneGiuseppeMuro''Evening Standard''5 October 201320 November 2013The Fortress (or Fortress Fulham),Thameside, The Friendy Confines, SW6, Lord of the Banks, The House of Hope, The Pavilion of Perfection, The 'True'Fulham Palaceand The Palatial Home. The Thames at the banks of the Cottage is often referred to as 'Old Father'cite webhttp://clockenders.com/afc/?pFULHAM 2 V 2 ARSENALAussieJackClockenders20 November 2013cite webhttp://www.fulham.vitalfootball.co.uk/article.asp?aFulham 2 Hamburg 1AndrewJoyceVital Football30 April 201020 November 2013cite webhttp://walsall.web-fans.com/2009/05/the-darlo-saddler-blogs-issue-no-29/The ‘Darlo Saddler’ Blogs – Issue No. 29DarloSaddlerWalsall Web-Fans23 May 200920 November 2013orThe River of Dreams.

The most accessible route to the ground is to walk through Bishops Park fromPutney Bridge tube stationPutney Bridge(the nearest Underground station),cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/help/faq/travelling-to-the-gameTravelling to the GameFulham F.C.21 November 2013often known as 'The Green Mile' by Fulham fans (as it is roughly a mile walk through pleasant greenery).cite webhttp://youdontknowjackfrombordeaux.wordpress.com/2013/05/12/judgment-day-finding-my-premier-league-club-in-london/Judgment Day: Finding my Premier League Club in LondonYou Don't Know Jack from Bordeaux12 May 201321 November 2013
article.heading: Plans
article.paragraph: On 27 July 2012, Fulham FC were granted permission to redevelop the Riverside Stand, increasing the capacity of Craven Cottage to 30,000 seats.cite webhttp://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11681/7939236/Cottage-expansion-grantedCottage expansion granted''Sky Sports''27 July 201218 November 2013cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2011/october/08/fulham-foreverFulham Foreverfulhamfc.comBeforehand various rumours arose including plans to return to ground-sharing with QPR in a new 40,000 seater White City stadium,cite webhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2370480/Fayed-scheme-for-Fulham-switch-to-new-White-City-stadium.htmlFayed scheme for Fulham switch to new White City stadiumMihirBose''Daily Telegraph''1 January 200421 November 2013cite webhttp://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/3774/the-sweeper/2012/01/28/2869994/the-sweeper-fulham-approached-by-qpr-about-interest-in-sharing-a-The Sweeper: Fulham approached by QPR about interest in sharing a new stadiumWayneVerseygoal.com28 January 201221 November 2013although these now appear firmly on hold with the construction of theWestfield LondonWestfieldshopping centre on the proposed site. The board seem to have moved away from their ambition to make Fulham the "Manchester United of the south" as it became clear how expensive such a plan would be.cite webhttp://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2013/aug/08/premier-league-preview-fulhamPremier League preview No7: FulhamPaulDoyle''Guardian''8 August 201321 November 2013With large spaces of land at a premium in south-west London, Fulham appear to be committed to a gradual increase of the ground's capacity often during the summer between seasons. The capacity of Craven Cottage has been increased during summers for instance in 2008 with a small increase in the capacity of the Hammersmith End. Fulham previously announced in 2007 that they are planning to increase the capacity of Craven Cottage by 4,000 seats,cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/Club/News/NewsArticles/2007/October/CottageRelease.aspxhttp://web.archive.org/web/20120421203942/http://www.fulhamfc.com/Club/News/NewsArticles/2007/October/CottageRelease.aspx21 April 2012Stadium AnnouncementFulham F.C.3 April 200718 November 2013but this is yet to be implemented. There was also proposals for a bridge to span the Thames, for a redeveloped Riverside stand and a museum.cite newshttp://www.theguardian.com/football/2003/jan/17/newsstory.sport8?INTCMPThe GuardianPaulKelsoDevelopment at Craven Cottage to include museum17 January 2003

More substantial plans arose in October 2011 with the 'Fulham Forever' campaign.cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/stadium-developmentStadium Development - Fulham Football Clubfulhamfc.comWith Al-Fayed selling hisHarrodsdepartment store for 1.5 billion in May 2010cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8669657.stmMohammed Al Fayed sells Harrods store to Qatar HoldingsBBC News8 May 201021 November 2013it is reasonable to presume that some of this money which has kick-started this larger scale plan into life. A detailed plan into the possibilities of expansion highlighted the Riverside Stand as the only viable area for expansion. The scheme involves the demolition of the back of the Riverside Stand with a new tier of seating added on top of the current one and a row of corporate boxes; bringing Craven Cottage up to 30,000 capacity.cite webhttp://www.stadiumguide.com/fulham-and-brighton-push-for-stadium-expansion/Fulham and Brighton push for stadium expansion [UPDATED]The Stadium GuideAs this would be a major project in a sensitive area the club has taken into consideration many points local residents may have problems with. The riverside walk would be re-opened, light pollution would be reduced with the removal of floodlight masts, new access points would make match-day crowds more manageable and the new stand would be respectful in design to its position on the River Thames. Although there is no time scheme for when the project will begin, the club is already far into the consultation phase and it appeared would like to begin soon during 2012-13.cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/stadium-development/construction-phaseConstruction Phase - Fulham Football Clubfulhamfc.comBuckingham Group Contracting were chosen in March 2013 as the construction company for the project.cite webhttp://www.constructionenquirer.com/2013/03/12/buckingham-set-to-score-with-15m-fulham-refurb/Buckingham set to score with £15m Fulham refurbconstructionenquirer.com
article.heading: The ground as it stands
Hammersmith End
article.paragraph: File:The Hammersmith End - Fulham FC, SW6 - geograph.org.uk - 934070.jpgthumbrightThe Hammy EndTheHammersmithEnd (or Hammy) is the northernmost stand in the ground, the closest to Hammersmith. The roofing was financed through the sale ofAlan MullerytoTottenham Hotspur F.C.Spurs.It is traditionally the "home" end where the more vocal Fulham fans sit,cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/help/faq/a-to-z-reference-guidesA to Z Reference GuidesFulham F.C.21 November 2013cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/help/faq/visiting-the-cottageVisiting The CottageFulham F.C.21 November 2013and many stand during games at the back rows of the stand. If Fulham win the toss, they usually choose to play towards the Hammersmith End in the second half. The stand had terracing until the reopening of the ground in 2004, when it was replaced with seating in order to comply with league rules following theTaylor Report.For several seasons, national flags of the players represented at Fulham were hung from the roof.:File:Fulham v Pompey (1).JPG#fileThere is a large permanent banner in the river corner reading "We Are Fulham".cite webhttp://cravencottagenewsround.wordpress.com/2008/03/01/slouching-towards-cheltenham-fulham-0-3-manchester-utd/Slouching towards Cheltenham: Fulham 0-3 Manchester UtdCraven Cottage Newsround1 March 200821 November 2013File:Australia vs New Zealand.jpgthumbrightThe 'Little Switzerland' section of the Putney End seen in the background during anAustralia national association football teamAustraliavsNew Zealand national football teamNew Zealandfriendly in 2005
article.heading: Putney End
article.paragraph: ThePutneyEnd is the southernmost stand in the ground, nearest toPutneyand backing onto Bishops Park. This generally hosts visiting and 'neutral' supporters,though often this is mixed with home and away fans. When the ground became redeveloped, with the standing terraces replaced in 2003-04 the club applied for a licence to have a designated neutral area, in the rows closest to the Cottage, (nicknamed 'Little Switzerland'.cite webhttp://bryanprzybilla.wordpress.com/2013/01/31/a-reminder-of-the-past-craven-cottage-brings-out-the-old-time-feel/A Reminder of the Past: Craven Cottage Brings Out the Old-Time FeelTravel across Europe for J-Term) Due to Fulham's history of having no segregation in the Putney End and no history of crowd trouble, the FA gave the club special dispensation to allow for this, making Fulham the only club currently in the UK to have such an area.cite webhttp://www.shoot.co.uk/stadium-special-4/Stadium specialGeorgePreece''Shoot''17 September 201325 November 2013Flags of every nationality in the Fulham squad were hung from the roofing, although they were removed after the 200607 season commenced and there is now an electronic scoreboard in place. There is a plane tree in the corner by the river,cite webhttp://www.flickr.com/photos/epltalk/304406352/Tree at Craven CottageTheGafferFlickr23 November 200621 November 2013the only remaining tree in a senior British football ground.
article.heading: Riverside Stand
article.paragraph: File:Boat Race Craven Cottage.jpgthumbrightThe current Riverside Stand beside theRiver ThamesThe Riverside was originally terracing that backed onto the Thames.It also featured large advertising hoardings above the fans.By 1973, a proper seated stand had been built called theEric Miller (businessman)Eric MillerStand (one of the directors at the time).The stand was opened in a prestigious friendly againstS.L. Benfica, who includedEusbioin the team.The name of the stand became called simply The Riverside after the discovery of Eric Miller's suicide, who had been under investigation for fraud and embezzlement.

The Riverside Stand backs onto theRiver Thamesand is elevated uniquely above the pitchcite webhttp://webzoom.freewebs.com/questforthe92/Fulham%20-%20Riverside%20Stand.JPGFulham - Riverside Stand.JPGRichardHooperQuest for the 9221 November 2013unlike the other 3 stands. It contains the corporate hospitality seatingalongside Fulham fans.Jimmy Hillonce referred to the Riverside being "a bit like the London Palladium" as Blocks V & W (the middle section) are often filled with the rich and famous (including often Al-Fayed). There are severalHarrodsadvertising boardings and above these is the gantry, for the press and cameras.Tickets in this area are often the easiest to buy, not surprisingly they are also some of the more expensive.cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/tickets/season-tickets/pricing-and-stadium-map2013/14 Season Ticket PricesFulham F.C.21 November 2013It has the Hammersmith End to its left, the Putney End to its right and is opposite theJohnny HaynesStand.

During the 1970s, Craven Cottage flooded, with water gushing in from the Riverside. The stand houses theGeorge Cohenrestaurant,cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/hospitality/packages/george-cohen-restaurantGeorge Cohen RestaurantFulham F.C.21 November 2013while on non-match days there is the Cottage Cafe, located near to the Cottage itself.(The River Caf (London)The River Cafis also located nearby).cite webhttp://www.rivercafe.co.uk/rc_page.php?pg_idRiver CaféRiver Café21 November 2013cite webhttps://maps.google.co.uk/maps?qloc: 51.483889,-0.224167Google Maps21 November 2013UnderTommy Trinder's chairmanship in the 60s, flags of all other teams in the Division 1 were proudly flown along the Thames.However, when Fulham were relegated in 1968,cite webhttp://www.statto.com/football/teams/fulham/1967-1968/tableFulham 1967-1968 : English Division One (old) TableStatto22 November 2013Trinder decided not to change the flags as "Fulham won't be in this division next season". True to Trinder's prophecy, Fulham were relegated again.cite webhttp://www.statto.com/football/teams/fulham/1968-1969/tableFulham 1968-1969 : English Division Two (old) TableStatto22 November 2013There is now a campaign to bring back the flags again.Citation neededMay 2008The roof of the stand has been used by sponsors, withFxProcurrently advertising in this way,cite webhttp://www.independent.co.uk/incoming/article7981884.ece/BINARY/original/Craven-Cottage.jpgindependent.co.uk''Independent''22 November 2013andPipexPipex.com,cite webhttp://www.premierfootballbooks.co.uk/images/fulham_aerial.jpgpremierfootballbooks.co.ukPremier Football Books22 November 2013Lee CooperLee Cooper JeansandLG CorpLGcite webhttp://farm3.staticflickr.com/2463/3586034488_bf80d76046_z.jpg?zzstaticflickr.comFlickr22 November 2013having previously done so. The end of the Riverside Stand towards the 'Smithy' End' indicates the end of the 'Fulham Wall', which is theMilestonemile postinThe Boat Race.
article.heading: Johnny Haynes Stand
article.paragraph: File:Ccffc.jpgthumbrightTheJohnny Haynesstand at Craven Cottage, is a Grade II* listed building.File:INTERIOR MONTAGE OF HAYNES STAND.jpgthumbrightInternal look of the stand, with a montage ofJohnny HaynesOriginally called the Stevenage Road Stand,after the road it backs onto,cite webhttp://www.footballgroundguide.com/fulham/#Craven-Cottage-Fulham-LayoutFootball Ground Guide: Craven Cottage, Fulham FC - Ground LayoutFootball Ground Guide25 November 2013the Johnny Haynes stand is the oldest remaining football stand in the Football League and professional football,originally constructed in 1905,and is a Grade II*listed building.Designed byArchibald Leitch,the stand contains the ticket officeand club shopand features original 'Bennet' wooden seating.Following his death in 2005, the stand was renamed after former playerJohnny Haynes.cite webhttp://wanderlustmarriage.com/the-oldest-football-stand-craven-cottage/The oldest football stand, Craven CottageWanderlust Marriage

The exterior facing Stevenage Road has a brick faadecite webhttp://www.flickr.com/photos/25645678@N06/sets/72157621791140557/detail/Craven Cottage Fulham FC Inside & OutFlickr1 August 200925 November 2013and features the club's old emblem in the artwork.Decorative pillars show the club's foundation date as 1880 though this is thought to be incorrect. Also, a special stone to commemorate Fulham 2000 and The Cottagers' return to Craven Cottage was engraved on the faade.The family enclosures are located in the two corners of the stand, one nearest to the Hammersmith End and one nearest to the Putney End.cite webhttp://www.fulhamfc.com/tickets/-/media/Tickets/Season%20Tickets/2013-14/Family%20Zone%20Season%20Ticket.ashxFamily Zone Season TicketsFulham F.C.25 November 2013The front of the stand now contains plastic seating, but originally was a standing area. Children were often placed at the front of this enclosure and the area had a distinctive white picket fence to keep fans off the pitch up until the 1970s.
article.heading: The Pavilion
article.paragraph: File:Fulham Football Club, Craven Cottage - geograph.org.uk - 577769.jpgthumbrightThe Pavilion from outside the stadiumThe Cottage Pavilion dates back to 1905 along with theJohnny HaynesStand,built by renowned football architectArchibald Leitch.The reason The Cottage was built was due to an oversight in the Stevenage Road Stand (as it was then), as Leitch had forgotten to accommodate changing rooms in his final plans.cite webhttp://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/article/away-day-guide-fulham-872498.aspxAway Day Guide: FulhamCrystal Palace F.C.29 July 201325 November 2013Besides being the changing rooms, the Cottage (also called The Clubhouse) is traditionally used by the players' families and friends who sit on the balcony to watch the game.In the past, board meetings used to be held in The Cottage itself as well. There is a large tapestry draped from the Cottage which says "Still Believe". It encapsulates the now-famous moment, when fans facing defeat againstHamburg SVin theEuropa Leaguesemi-final roused the players with the chant of "Stand up if you still believe".cite webhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/fulham/7653889/Fulham-v-Hamburg-Roy-Hodgson-shows-his-England-manager-credentials.htmlFulham v Hamburg: Roy Hodgson shows his England manager credentialsJohnLey''Daily Telegraph''29 April 201025 November 2013cite webhttp://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/apr/30/fulham-hamburg-europa-leagueFulham's greatest game sees them back on the road to HamburgDavidHytner''Guardian''30 April 201025 November 2013cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/philmcnulty/2010/04/hodgson_takes_the_acclaim.htmlHodgson and Fulham deserve the acclaimPhilMcNultyBBC Sport30 April 201025 November 2013In the three other corners of the ground there are what have been described as large 'filing cabinets', which are corporate boxes on three levels.cite av mediahttp://www.youtube.com/watch?vFulham Football Club - History Compilation2 July 2006YouTube

article.heading: All-time attendance

list.listitem: Total attendance:31,234,275 (Correct up to January 2013)cite webhttp://www.fulham-mad.co.uk/news/tmnw/fulhams_average_league_attendances_492403/index.shtmlFulham's Average League AttendancesFootymad Limitedfulham-mad.co.uk
Average total attendance:15,759 (ranked 31 of 130 English club teams in history)

link.target: Ground improvements at English football Stadia

article.heading: International matches
article.paragraph: File:2011 UEFA Women's Champions League Final.jpgthumbright200pxView of the Riverside during the2011 UEFA Women's Champions League FinalOn February 22, 2000, it hostedEngland under-21 national football teamEnglands under 21sinternational under 21 friendly againstArgentina national under-21 football teamArgentinas under 21s. The hosts won 1-0 withLee Hendries sixty seventh minute goal with 15,747 in attendance.

In recent years, Craven Cottage has hosted several International Friendly matches, including theRepublic of Ireland national football teamIreland national teamwho played Colombia and Nigeria there in May 2008cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/7426669.stmRep of Ireland 1-0 ColombiaBBC Sport29 May 200825 November 2013and May 2009cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/8074830.stmRep of Ireland 1-1 NigeriaAlvinMcCaigBBC Sport29 May 200925 November 2013respectively andOman national football teamOmanin 2012.TheSouth Korea national football teamhave also used the ground thrice in recent years for international friendlies, first against Greece in February 2007second against Serbia in November 2009,cite webhttp://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/112490/reportSouth Korea v SerbiaSky Sports18 November 200926 November 2013and then against Croatia in February 2013.cite webhttp://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/102620/south-korea-vs-croatia/lineup-statsSouth Korea vs Croatia Lineups and Statisticsgoal.com6 February 201326 November 2013On 17 November 2007 Australia beat Nigeria 10 in an international friendly at Craven Cottage.Sky Sports Match Commentary http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/103218/commentary and http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/92043In 26 May 2011, Craven Cottage hosted the game of2011 UEFA Women's Champions League FinalbetweenOlympique Lyonnais FmininLyonand1. FFC Turbine PotsdamPotsdam. In September 2011, a friendly betweenGhana national football teamGhanaandBrazil national football teamBrazilwas also held at Craven Cottage.On the 15th of October, 2013, Australia beat Canada 3-0 at Craven Cottage. On 28 May 2014 Scotland played out a 2-2 draw with a Nigerian team who had qualified for the 2014 World Cup Finals.
article.heading: Other

link.part: Michael Jackson statue at Craven Cottage

list.listitem: Harlequins Rugby League#Fulham Rugby League ClubFulham Rugby League Club, now London Broncos, played at Craven Cottage between 1980 and 1984,hosting their largest attendance.The ground has also hosted Oxbridge varsity matches in rugby and football.
The ground has hosted the mostAustralia national association football teamAustralia national teammatches outside ofAustraliaand was one of the pioneers in hosting (neutral) international friendlies.

Fulham were the last team to have standing accommodation in thePremier League, as Craven Cottage included terraces in the2001-02 in English football200102 seasoneight years after theTaylor Reportoutlawed terraces at this level.

The original Craven Cottage site was covered in woodlands.cite webhttp://premierskills.britishcouncil.org/clubs/fulhamLearn English with the Premier LeagueBritish Council26 November 2013OnePlatanusplane treesurvives today in a corner of the Putney End,the sole tree to be found in any British senior football stadium.

On 3 April 2011, Fulham unveiled aMichael Jackson StatuestatueofMichael Jacksoninside the stadium before its match with Blackpool. The singer, who died in 2009, was not a Fulham fan and had no interest in football whatsoever, but attended a Fulham match once, saying "Fulham fans were like people at my concerts. I wanted to jump up and start dancing";cite newshttp://www.theguardian.com/football/2005/aug/08/newsstory.sport48?INTCMPLondonThe GuardianFulham8 August 2005and was friends with club chairmanMohamed Al-Fayed, who commissioned the statue.ESPN, "Michael Jackson statue unveiled." http://espn.go.com/sports/soccer/news/_/id/6286197/statue-michael-jackson-unveiled-fulham-home-stadiumcite newshttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-12950708BBC NewsMichael Jackson Fulham FC statue defended by Al Fayed3 April 2011In 2013, Al-Fayed stated that the statue will be moved to a different property he owns.cite newsRiceSimonhttp://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/michael-jackson-statue-set-to-be-removed-from-fulham-stadium-craven-cottage-at-mohamed-al-fayeds-request-8826503.htmlMichael Jackson statue set to be removed from Fulham stadium Craven Cottage at Mohamed Al Fayed's request[[The Independent]]19 September 201319 September 2013
